populated place

activity-description.narrative: The project will work on improving the infrastructure of Iona National Park, training its staff and developing studies about its flora, fauna and communities in order to rehabilitate the park.

description.narrative: independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Strengthen institutional capacity to manage the protected areas network in Angola

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Park Manager and staff deployed, environmental assessment and infrastructures construction initiated, appropriate park equipment procured, functioning information sharing, conditions prepared for the elaboration of the Iona NP management plan, community profile report elaborated, human-Wildlife conflict issues identified 2. PLERNACA plan and engagement strategy implemented and adopted, human resources development programme for PAs implemented, evaluation implemented in 9 PAs, 6 PAs selected for further study, TORs created, project operation enabled 3. Staff employed, equipped and installed, project management enabled, communication plan implemented, database created and maintained

comment.narrative: 1. No existing staff, unsufficient infrastructure, lack of communcation and planning, basic level of Government support exists 2. "Strategic Plan for a National Network of Conservation Areas" (PLERNACA) approved, National Biodiversity Directorate (DNB) responsible for PAs at policy level and INBAC at implementation level, but for improved organizational, institutional and technical capacity is needed, limited information on the existing PAs, no management or implementation plan for any PA, Office space provided, ME officer employed since Sep. 2012 3. Project to be initiated in 2013, Project Manager employed since Sept 2012, PAA selected, insufficient awareness and visibility to Angolan PAs at all levels
1. Iona Park management plan finalized 2. Community engagement activities in Iona designed and initiated 3. 6 protected areas studies completed

1. Management plan finalized and communicated to stakeholders 2. Community engagement activities identified, designed and implementation contracted with company or NGO 3. Studies contracted and completed

description.narrative: Objective Catalyze an improvement in the overall management of the protected areas network through rehabilitating Iona National Park

description.narrative:
5 Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool scorecard
Iona National Park

comment.narrative:
5 points out of 102 possible giving Jan 2012 5
NOTE ON LOGFRAME 2014
We need to make a correction to the baseline In the PRODOC it mentions a 7 rate However 5 points was the final baseline score and all questions were considered none considered na This gives a total possible points of 102 and a percentage of 5 at the baseline

Target achieved but this needs to be independently vetted Considerable improvement in the METT score has been attained since the original evaluation of November 20 2011 The June 2015 METT evaluation returned a score of 32102 31 in comparison with only 5102 5 in 2011 In the 2011 assessment only three questions 1 5 6 were awarded positive scores totaling 5 of a possible 9 points The same total score for these three questions was also awarded in 2015 However of the 39 questions that received zero scores in 2011 23 received positive scores in the recent evaluation indicating a wideranging improvement in management effectiveness The target of at least 45 in the final evaluation is considered attainable

description.narrative: 6 Number of park management staff appointed equipped trained and deployed in the park

comment.narrative: Approaching target Same as last year

description.narrative: 7 Percentage of park visitors obtaining a permit to traverseovernight in the park

comment.narrative: At least 80

Progress made towards the target 40 of Park visitors is reported Registration and entry fees collection pilot system launch in October 2014 has been reformulated and submitted to the local government authority for approval

description.narrative: 8 Proportion of the plains grassland habitats of the park 600km2 overgrazed by livestock goats and cattle

comment.narrative: More than 35 by 201112
Less than 20

Not possible to assess the indicator with accuracy but there are good indications that the baseline may have been optimistic and the target even more so The aerial survey is yet to be conducted Observations from the ground indicate an increase of at least 40 of the grassland habitats of the park overgrazed by livestock

HCFC phase -out management plan (stage I, third tranche)
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Government commitment at the Decision XIX/6 of the Nineteenth Meeting of the Parties that accelerated the phase out of hydrochlorofluorocarbons in both Article 5 and non-Article 5 countries implemented.

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration
1) Level of implementation of the Regulatory Framework for hydroclorofluorocarbons 2) Number of sensitization program held 3) Refrigeration sector strengthened

comment.narrative: Consistent with the recommendations of ExCom guidance on Hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs), a staged approach to the hydroclorofluorocarbons is taken based on an established starting point for aggregate reduction in hydroclorofluorocarbons consumption estimated baseline of 15.95 Ozone Depleting Potential (ODP) tonnes, calculated using actual consumption of 19.25 Ozone Depleting Potential (ODP) tonnes and 12.65 ODP tonnes reported in 2009 and 2010, respectively, under Article 7 of the Montreal Protocol. It involves presentation of a high level long term strategy directed to meeting the 2020 (35% baseline reduction) and 2025 (67.5% baseline reduction) phase out targets and ultimately complete elimination of hydroclorofluorocarbons consumption in 2040.
1) Regulatory Framework for hydroclorofluorocarbons implemented 2) Number of sensitization program held 3) Refrigeration sector strengthened
1) Procurement of refrigerant recovery equipment and refrigeration maintenance tools kits held . 2)1 3) Ozone Depleting Substances consumption data audit for Angola was conducted.
1) Regulatory Framework for hydroclorofluorocarbons implemented 2) Number of sensitization program held 3) Refrigeration sector strengthened

1)The increase of import duty of hydrochlorofluorocarbons and hydrofluorocarbons contributes to the goal of 10% reduction in consumption 2) 1 3)The country is progressing in the use of hydrofluorocarbons and hydrocarbon
1) Regulatory Framework for hydroclorofluorocarbons implemented 2) Number of sensitization program held 3) Refrigeration sector strengthened

Sustainable Economy Development Inclusive Gowth
seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: promote inclusive business initiatives, entrepreneurship development and employment creation and efforts to diversify the Angolan economy away from the oil and diamond sectors.

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: promoted efforts to diversify the Angolan economy away from the oil and diamond sectors

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

1. Number and scope of new South-South and triangular cooperation partnerships, PPP mechanisms that provide innovative solutions for inclusive growth 2. Number of schemes enabled to expand and diversify employment and livelihood opportunities for youth and women 3. Number of plans, strategies and analytical reports produced using high-quality, disaggregated data. 4. Number of policies and schemes that enhance access to social protection for the poor and other risk groups

comment.narrative: 1. 0 new South-South and triangular cooperation partnerships, PPP mechanisms provided innovative solutions for inclusive growth 2. 1 schemes enabled to expand and diversify employment and livelihood opportunities for youth and women (National Youth Development Plan). 3. 0 plans, strategies and analytical reports produced using high-quality, disaggregated data. 4.1 policies and schemes that enhance access to social protection for the poor and other risk groups (Angola National Development Plan 2013 - 2017)

- Capacities of MIREX and the inter-ministerial Committee implement and monitor the graduation ‘Road-Map’ - MDPT impact study on potential impact of graduation on ODA completed. - Action plan designed and submitted to UN on graduation - Methodologies to identify and address needs for concentrated pockets of poverty developed and integrated in 3 strategies of selected Municipalities. - Facilitate the establishment of the country agribusiness supply chains and 3 sustainable value chain initiatives - Facilitate the conclusion of the National Strategy and action plan on domestic tourism - INAPEM strengthened for effective SMME development - National CSR Network established and functioning - Studies on strategies on increasing inclusive business practices and economic diversification promoted - Institutional framework for market oriented vocational education promoted. - Youth entrepreneurship competitions promoted. - At least one value chain benefiting women and youth developed. - MPTD supported to report on NDP and MDGs - Social Assistance Policy endorsed by National Assembly - MINARS strengthened for advocacy and implementation of new social policy

• Angola has to draft a Smooth Transition Strategy and Road Map and for that they count with the UN Support. The GoA expects to draft the Strategy along 2016. • UNDP is supported MINGEO with a consultancy on alignment of Angolan legislation and polices to the AMV. • The studies on comparative value chain and Fiscal Regime of gold sector was concluded • The National MDG Report conclude and thhe GoA, through MINPLAN is expecting before the end of the year to have a workshop with the UN support for the launching of the Angola MDGR 2015. At the same event the GoA with UN support wants to highlight the GoA with the SDGs, including a brief presentation of the SDGs in the same workshop. • The Noin-Oil Value Chain analysis was concluded • The National Corporate Social Responsibility established.

-Support the government in mainstreaming SDG in National Development Plan -Carried out the Human Development training -Support the road map to graduation from the LDC project -Support the Kukula Ku Muxi Project to leverage sustainable livelihood programme -Support Youth skills development and employment opportunities

-UNDP’s support on elaboration of Country Graduation Transition Strategic from the LDG status in collaboration with Ministry of Planning promoted a High level training workshop for 140 participants and led to elaboration of the Country graduation road map. - The consultancy for mainstreaming the SDG in the national development plan started and the final report will be available in 2017. -100 government official and CSO delegates trained on Human development issues and methodologies leading to preparation for NHDR is gained. -13000 families benefited from livelihood programme which lead to increase income and family competence skills. -2000 youths registered for international certificate programme and job opportunities internships. - 30,000 schoolchildren exposed to to learn for fist time computers skills and research facilitation

-Support the government in integration of SGD in Sectorial Plans -Support the government for preparation of the LDC graduation report and Road Map - Implementation of Angola Supply Development programme through promotion of value chains (horticulture, income generations activities and fish processing) -Support vocational training initiatives through MEDIATECASs and National Volunteer Programme.

activity-description.narrative: The project aims to improve the legal, planning, policy, institutional and financial frameworks for protected area expansion in Angola

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Strengthening the legal, planning, policy, institutional and financial frameworks for protected area expansion; 2. Rehabilitating, and improving the management of, three existing National Parks (Cangandala, Bicuar and Quiçama).

comment.narrative: 1. There is a need for improving the ecosystem representation and coverage through a Protected Areas expansion; 2. There is a lack of capability and resources to manage effectively and minimize threats to the National Parks of Quiçama, Bicuar and Cangandala.

1. Appointment of the National Project team. 2. Define an implementation plan for each park (Quiçama, Bicuar and Cangandala) 3. Define a specific strategy for outcome 1 (Expansion of Protected Areas) as agreed with MINAMB/ INBAC

1. The National Project team works effectivelly with the UNDP team 2. The implementation paln for each park is defined with the help of the local stakeholders. 3. The project has a well defined strategy for the Expansion of the Protected Areas.

comment.narrative: 1. MINFAMU sectorial plan, part of the National Development Plan - NDP (2013-2017) 2. National Policy on Gender Equality and Equity (PNIEG 2014 -2017) approved in 2013 3. Lack of data and weak institutional capacity

1. MINFAMU's capacity to promote and to monitor implementation of PNIEG and its Action Plan strengthened 1. MINFAMU's capacity to advocate and coordinate gender mainstreaming in development enhanced 1. National capacities for collection, analysis and utilization of gender disaggregated data reinforced

1. 145 women trained in skills and on legal framework for community organizing [2014-2015] 1. Gender equity and equality policy brochures published [2015] 1. MINFAMU staff participated in international forums on gender [2015] 1. Ongoing mapping of CSOs that work on gender [2015]

The coordination mechanism of the intersectorial gender network strengthened. The report on CSOs that work on gender mainstreaming was presented in July 2016. Based on its finding MINFAMU will be able to strategically engage with civil society organizations and align plans, programs and workout the SDGs jointly.
Support the National Capacity to Monitor and report SDG 5
National capacity to monitor and report SDG5 strenghened

title.narrative: LDCF/ climate-resilience Angola´s Cuvelai River Basin

description.narrative: This proposal seeks funding from the LDCF to implement a FSP, specifically in the region of Cuvelai River Basin (Cunene). The project will focus on two NAPA priorities: Create an early warning system and Climate monitoring and data management system.

title.narrative: PIMS 5166_Prodoc ANGOLA CUVELAI BASIN LDCF Final_160203

description.narrative: Promoting climate-resilient development and enhanced adaptive capacity to withstand disaster risks in Angolan’s Cuvelai River Basin
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Cunene Province is vulnerable to increasing frequency of droughts, floods impacting agriculture and livestock, water resources, rural development and food security, soil erosion. The project had technical meetings with local partners in order to start, as well as an OCHA mission to develop SOP´s for

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
Functioning early-warning system for flood and drought events in the Cuvelai basin Land use practices reducing the vulnerability of the population and its adaptive capacity

comment.narrative: Angola, particularly the Southern region of Cunene Province, is vulnerable to increasing frequency and severity of droughts, floods and severe storms and these events impact sectors such as agriculture and livestock, water resources, rural development and food security, as well as soil erosion, built infrastructures and livelihoods. Of particular concern are the Cuvelai River Basin communities and sectors such as agriculture, livestock and water resources which are an important component of the economy in the region and form the basis of rural livelihoods in Cuvelai Basin.
1) Project team set up 2) Initiation workshop completed 3) Detailed workplan for first year elaborated with stakeholders and approved by steering committee

1) The project has a clear decision making and implementation structure 2) The initiation workshop has successfully engaged local stakeholders and informed them about the project 3) The tasks for the first year have been discussed and agreed with local stakeholders and been agreed by the steering committee

1) Detailed workplan for second year elaborated with stakeholders and approved by Project Coordination team 2) Procurement of equipment for early warning system 3) Implementation of proposals of stakeholders in each of the components of the project (in order to create resilience to the affected communities at rural level, etc.; strength government institutions through capacity building),

1) At least 5 specific proposals implemented until the end of the year 2) At least 3 steering committee meetings in 2017 (political and technical level) 3) Early warning system equipment adquired and installed in Cuvelai Basin communities 4) Coordination Project team trained and working for the implementation of the project.

description.narrative: Health - policy, planning and administration

1) Number of technician trained on ME, data collection tools and stock management. 2) Number of GTNME meetings. 3) Number of health facility with SIS installed and operational. 4) Number of Provinces supervised regarding the use of thermometers, pharmacovigilance. 5) National formulary validated. (Note: The project started in 2015).

comment.narrative: 1) 338 technicians has been trained on ME, data collection tools and stock management. 2) The national ME group (GTNME) has been reactivated and TORs of the GTNME approved. 3) Software SIS installed at Province level. 4) Installation of thermometers in all the Provincials warehouse and health facilities. 5) List of essentials medicines validated and starting the elaboration of the National Formulary.
1) 70 2) 8 3) 5 4) 9 5) National formulary of medicines validated.

1) 80; 46 in ME issue, 19 in health system information and 15 in data collection 2) 1 3) 5 Municipality health facility 4) 8 5) The draft of the national formulary of essential medicines is read but needs to be revised by the specialist before the final validation
1) Support legal environment assessment to review legal barriers impeding access to services. 2) 5) National formulary of medicines validated. 3) transition project for the new global fund grant NFM
1) ToRs drafted, NGO selected evaluation will start next year 2) National formulary of essential medicines validated at tecnical level. 3) New Global Fund project signed.

description.narrative: 1) Number of women and men aged 15+ who received an HIV test and know their results 2) Percentage of young people aged 10-24 years reached by life skills-based HIV education, out of school 3) Percentage of MSM reached with HIV prevention programmes - individual and/or smaller group level interventions 4) Percentage of Sex Workers reached with HIV prevention programmes - defined package of services 5) Percentage of HIV-positive pregnant women who received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission 6) Percentage of infants born to HIV-positive women who received a virological test for HIV within 2 months of birth 7) Percentage of adults and children currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV 8) Percentage of children currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV 9) Percentage of new HIV-positive patients starting IPT during the reporting period 10) Percentage of TB patients who had an HIV test result recorded in the TB register 11) Percentage of HIV-positive patients who were screened for TB in HIV care and/or treatment setting 12) Percentage of HIV-positive registered TB patients given antiretroviral therapy during TB treatment

comment.narrative: 1) 1 191 972 men and women aged 15 years+ who received an HIV test and know their result (2014) 2) Percentage of young people aged 10-24 old reached with life skills-based HIV education, out of school : baseline not available 3) 5% of MSM reached with HIV Prevention programmes - individual or smaller group level interventions (2015) 4) 5.2% of Sex Workers reached with HIV Prevention programmes - defined package of services (2015) 5) 40.2% of HIV Positive pregnant women who received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission (2014) 6) 2% of infants born to HIV-Positive women who received a virological test within two months of birth (Sept 2014-Sept 2015) 7) 22.5% of adults and children currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV (2014) 8)15.3% of children currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV (2014) 9) Percentage of new HIV positive patients starting IPT during the reporting period : baseline not available 10) Percentage of TB patients who had an HIV test result recorded in the TB register : baseline not available 11) Percentage of HIV patients who were screened for TB in HIV treatment and/or care settings: baseline not available 12) Percentage of HIV positive registered TB patients who were given antiretroviral therapy during TB treatment : baseline not available

1) 350 000 women and men aged 15 years + received an HIV test and know their results 2) Young people aged 10-24 years reached by life skills-based HIV education out of school : no target for the reporting period 3) MSM reached with HIV prevention programmes - individual and/or smaller group level interventions : no target for the reporting period 4) Sex Workers reached with HIV prevention programmes - defined package of services : no target for the reporting period 5) 27.6% ( 3000 / 10 850) HIV-positive pregnant women who received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission 6) Infants born to HIV-positive women who received a virological test for HIV within 2 months of birth : no target for the reporting period 7) 27% (95.000 / 350 000) adults currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV 8) 9.7% (3000 / 31 000) children currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV 9) Percentage of new HIV-positive patients starting IPT during the reporting period : no target for the reporting period 10) Percentage of TB patients who had an HIV test result recorded in the TB register : no target for the reporting period 11) Percentage of HIV-positive patients who were screened for TB in HIV care and/or treatment setting : no target for the reporting period 12) Percentage of HIV-positive registered TB patients given antiretroviral therapy during TB treatment : no target for the reporting period

1) 346 507 women and men aged 15+ received an HIV test and know their results 2) Young people aged 10-24 years were reached by life skills-based HIV education out of school : no target / no result for the reporting period 3) MSM reached with HIV prevention programmes - individual and/or smaller group level interventions : no target / no result for the reporting period 4) 0 % (0 / 25 000) Sex Workers reached with HIV prevention programmes - defined package of services : no target / no result for the reporting period 5) 28 % (3047 / 10 850) HIV-positive pregnant women received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission 6) Infants born to HIV-positive women received a virological test for HIV within 2 months of birth : no target / no result for the reporting period 7) 26.6% ( 93 349) adults currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV 8) 21.1% ( 6538) children currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV 9) Percentage of new HIV-positive patients starting IPT during the reporting period : no target / no result for the reporting period 10) Percentage of TB patients who had an HIV test result recorded in the TB register : no target / no result for the reporting period 11) Percentage of HIV-positive patients who were screened for TB in HIV care and/or treatment setting : no target / no result for the reporting period 12) Percentage of HIV-positive registered TB patients given antiretroviral therapy during TB treatment : no target / no result for the reporting period

1) 2 575 000 women and men aged 15+ received an HIV test and know their results 2) 7 % (10 500 / 150 000) young people aged 10-24 years reached by life skills-based HIV education, out of school 3) 5.6% ( 500 / 9000) MSM reached with HIV prevention programmes - individual and/or smaller group level interventions 4) 24% ( 6 000 / 25 000) Sex Workers reached with HIV prevention programmes - defined package of services 5) 12 100 HIV-positive pregnant women received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission 6) 14% (1300 / 9540) infants born to HIV-positive women received a virological test for HIV within 2 months of birth 7) 29% (105 000 / 359 000) Adults currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV 8) 20% (6500 / 32 000) Children currently receiving antiretroviral therapy among all adults and children living with HIV 9) 13% (27 500 / 210 000) Percentage of new HIV-positive patients starting IPT during the reporting period 10) 72% (51 971 / 72 685) Percentage of TB patients who had an HIV test result recorded in the TB register 11) 6% (12 500 / 210 000) Percentage of HIV-positive patients who were screened for TB in HIV care and/or treatment setting 12) 3 350 HIV-positive registered TB patients given antiretroviral therapy during TB treatment
Results as of 30th June 2017 will be available by 31st July 2017.
